articles.title: When to Start Complementary Feeding: Signs Your Baby Is Ready
articles.teaser: How to determine if your baby is ready for the first solids and choose the perfect moment.

cover.caption: First spoonfuls of complementary food for a curious baby

data.text: Introducing complementary foods is an important milestone in your baby's development when they move from exclusive breastmilk or formula to new foods. Choosing the right time to start affects not only appetite, but also the development of the digestive system, eating habits, and even future attitudes toward food.
The best age to start complementary feeding

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) and pediatricians in most countries, solids should be introduced at around 6 months. Until then, breastmilk or formula fully covers your baby's nutritional needs.
Some babies may be ready a little earlier‚Äîat 5 months‚Äîwhile others only closer to 7 months. The main thing is not to rush and to focus not only on age but also on readiness cues.
Readiness signs to watch for
Every child develops at their own pace, so it is important to observe their behavior. Below are the key signals that show it's time to introduce new tastes.
1. Your baby holds their head steady
Your baby should be able to hold their head upright and sit with minimal support. This is crucial for safety so there is no risk of choking during meals.
2. Shows interest in family meals
If your baby watches you eat with fascination, reaches for the spoon, or tries to grab a piece, it's a sign they are curious about new foods.
3. The tongue-thrust reflex has faded
Newborns have a natural tongue-thrust reflex that automatically pushes out anything thicker than milk. Once this reflex fades, your baby can handle pur√©ed textures.
4. Bigger appetite and milk is not enough
If your baby asks to feed more often but still seems unsatisfied afterward, it may mean their body needs more nutrients.
5. Weight has doubled since birth
Doubling their birth weight is another readiness marker. It shows that your baby is growing actively and needs extra energy.
6. No signs of illness
Start solids only when your baby is healthy, without colds, tummy troubles, or teething discomfort that could cause a temporary refusal of new foods.
When to postpone complementary feeding
Don't introduce new foods if your baby is ill or has just received vaccinations.
Avoid starting during heat waves because of the risk of dehydration.
Delay the introduction if you notice major stress or routine changes, such as moving house or a new caregiver.
Wait if your baby still can't hold their head steady or sit on their own.
How to prepare for the first feeding
1. Pick the right time of day‚Äîwhen your baby is alert, not too hungry, and in a good mood.
2. Start with a single food and observe the reaction for 2‚Äì3 days.
3. Don't force it‚Äîif your baby turns away or presses their lips together, simply try again later.
4. Offer food with a spoon, not from a bottle‚Äîthis helps your baby learn to swallow correctly.
5. Keep notes‚Äîmaintain a small feeding diary or use a mobile app.
Early or late? Why balance matters
Introducing solids too early, before 4 months, can overload the digestive system and raise the risk of allergies and tummy issues.
Starting too late, after 8 months, can lead to iron deficiency, refusal of textured foods, and delays in developing chewing skills.
The best strategy is to focus on your baby's readiness rather than fixed dates on the calendar.
Introducing solids isn't only about food‚Äîit's a new step in your baby's development. When you notice readiness cues, offer new tastes slowly, with care and curiosity.
Remember: every spoonful is a small discovery, a step toward independence and new sensations.

articles.title: First Foods for Complementary Feeding: What to Offer First
articles.teaser: A guide to the vegetables and cereals that work best for the first solids and how to safely introduce new tastes.

cover.caption: Pur√©es and cereals as first complementary dishes

data.text: Starting solids is a new stage in your baby's life and an important step for parents. After six months, breastmilk or formula alone is no longer enough, so babies gradually need extra foods. But where do you begin to keep everything safe and beneficial?
Which food to choose first

There are several ways to start solids, and the choice often depends on health, weight gain, and your doctor's advice. Pediatricians usually recommend single-ingredient vegetable or grain pur√©es so your baby's body can adapt gradually.
Option 1. Vegetable pur√©e
Ideal for babies who are gaining weight quickly or already have a higher weight.
The first vegetables usually include:
- zucchini;
- cauliflower;
- broccoli;
- pumpkin.
They are easy to digest, rarely cause allergies, and have a delicate flavor similar to breastmilk. Prepare the pur√©e without salt or spices, starting with 1‚Äì2 teaspoons per day.
Option 2. Gluten-free cereals
If your baby gains weight slowly or seems low on energy, start with single-ingredient, dairy-free cereals:
- rice;
- buckwheat;
- corn.
Cook the cereal in water or mix it with breastmilk or formula. The key is no sugar, salt, or additives.
Option 3. Fruit pur√©e
Fruits taste great and babies get used to them quickly, but don't rush. Offer them after vegetables so your little one doesn't refuse less sweet meals.
Good first options are:
- apple;
- pear;
- banana (from 7 months).
How to introduce the first foods
1. Start with one ingredient. Offer each new food on its own so it's easier to track any reaction.
2. Increase the amount gradually. Begin with 1 teaspoon and slowly work up to a full serving‚Äî100‚Äì150 g per day.
3. Watch for reactions. If there is no rash, tummy ache, or change in stool, you can add another food after 3‚Äì4 days.
4. Cook without salt, sugar, or spices. The natural taste of the ingredients is all your baby needs.
5. Choose the right timing. Offer new foods in the daytime‚Äîbetween morning and midday feeds‚Äîwhen your baby is in a good mood.
Sample first-week menu
- Days 1‚Äì3: zucchini pur√©e ‚Äî 1 tsp ‚Üí 3‚Äì4 tsp.
- Days 4‚Äì6: cauliflower pur√©e ‚Äî 1 tsp ‚Üí 5 tsp.
- Days 7‚Äì10: zucchini + cauliflower, or switch to buckwheat cereal.
From 7 months you can add potato, carrot, pumpkin, apple, pear, and later meat.
Common mistakes when starting solids
- Starting before your baby can sit or hold their head.
- Offering several new foods at once.
- Adding salt or sugar.
- Pressuring your baby to eat when they don't want to.
- Offering solids during illness or right after vaccinations.
Remember: complementary feeding is not a race but a gentle introduction to a world of new flavors.
When to call the doctor
Contact your pediatrician if you notice after a new food:
- rash or redness;
- diarrhea or constipation;
- frequent spit-ups;
- restlessness or disrupted sleep;
- swelling or breathing difficulties‚Äîstop the new food immediately and see a pediatrician or allergist.
Tips for parents
- Breastmilk or formula remains the main source of nutrition up to age one.
- Create a positive mealtime setting: smile and keep your voice calm.
- Let your baby touch the spoon and try feeding themselves‚Äîit sparks curiosity and fine motor skills.
- If something isn't liked, take a break for a few days and offer it again.
Takeaway
First complementary foods should be simple, safe, and natural. Start with vegetables or cereals, watch your baby closely, and add new dishes step by step.
Above all, stay calm, unhurried, and caring. Every new spoonful is your baby's step into the big world of family meals.

articles.title: BLW (Baby-Led Weaning) or Self-Feeding ‚Äî a Modern Way to Introduce Solids
articles.teaser: What the BLW approach is, how to assess readiness, and how to organize safe self-feeding.

cover.caption: A baby exploring solid food independently during the first meal

data.text: What is BLW
BLW (baby-led weaning) isn't a type of food but an approach where the baby takes the lead in feeding from the very first solid meals.
The idea was formulated by Gill Rapley‚Äîa British nurse, lactation consultant, and researcher.
BLW spread worldwide thanks to its simple yet revolutionary concept:
‚ÄúThe child leads their own feeding, and adults provide a safe, natural environment.‚Äù
Benefits of self-feeding
- encourages healthy eating habits from infancy;
- builds coordination and fine motor skills;
- stimulates sensory development through touch, taste, and smell;
- reduces the risk of overeating and picky eating later on;
- strengthens the emotional bond between child and parents during meals.
When to start BLW
Self-feeding is suitable for babies around 6 months old when they:
- can sit independently or with minimal support;
- hold their head steady;
- can grab food with their hands and bring it to their mouth.
Before you start, make sure your baby is physically ready‚Äîtheir digestive system, chewing skills, and postural stability should be developed enough.
The World Health Organization also recommends introducing solids after 6 months while continuing breastfeeding.
Core rules of BLW
1. Safety first. Your baby should sit upright to coordinate swallowing and breathing.
2. Don't spoon-feed. Let your baby decide what, when, and how much to eat.
3. Never leave your baby unattended while eating.
4. Skip salt, sugar, honey, and spices.
5. Offer soft foods in safe shapes and sizes.
6. Serve water in a cup or open glass, not in a sippy cup.
7. No gadgets or TV during meals.
8. Breastmilk or formula remains the main food until one year.
How to set up mealtime
- seat your baby in a comfortable high chair with a footrest;
- choose plain dishware without patterns to reduce distractions;
- use a suction plate or silicone mat;
- place a mat or cloth under the chair‚Äîmess is inevitable at the start;
- prepare a silicone bib with a pocket;
- serve foods as long strips or sticks roughly adult-finger size.
Safe ways to serve food
Check the texture: if the food squishes easily between your fingers, it's safe.
Start with soft vegetables and fruits‚Äîbroccoli, cauliflower, carrot, zucchini, avocado, banana, steamed apple.
Gradually add other foods such as cereals, meat, legumes, and eggs.
The key is to take it slow and introduce new ingredients gradually while watching your baby's reactions.
Choking risk and natural reflexes
Parents often worry about choking, but studies show the risk with BLW is no higher than with traditional spoon-feeding.
Babies have a strong gag reflex‚Äîa natural safety mechanism that keeps pieces from going too far down the throat.
Important:
- don't put your hands or a spoon into your baby's mouth;
- don't pat them on the back;
- calmly allow them to cough it out;
- intervene only if the baby isn't breathing, makes no sound, and turns blue.
What to offer first
For the first attempts choose soft foods that can be mashed with the gums:
- cooked vegetables (carrot, pumpkin, potato, broccoli);
- fruit (banana, pear, avocado);
- soft meat or meatballs;
- thick porridges shaped into strips;
- toast, pasta, egg, fish‚Äîintroduced gradually by age.
Combining with a spoon
BLW doesn't ban spoons if the baby holds them independently.
Starter pre-spoon utensils with small ridges work best.
Make sure pur√©es are thick, not runny, so the baby can stay in control.
When BLW isn't suitable
Avoid this approach for babies with:
- dysphagia (swallowing difficulties);
- hypotonia or developmental delays;
- structural issues of the mouth;
- low weight, anemia, or prematurity (without pediatric approval).
Global experience and recommendations
- WHO emphasizes starting complementary foods at 6 months while continuing breastfeeding up to 2 years or longer.
- The American Academy of Pediatrics considers BLW safe if adults supervise and choose appropriate textures.
- The UK National Health Service notes that self-feeding helps babies recognize hunger and fullness and builds independence.
- Systematic reviews in BMJ Open and the International Journal of Pediatrics show BLW diets provide similar nutrition, but it's crucial to monitor iron intake and avoid hard chunks.
BLW is a natural, mindful, and respectful way to support your child's development.
It fosters independence, builds a healthy relationship with food, and creates a positive mealtime atmosphere.
Parents should stay close, support, and trust their little one.
The ultimate goal of solids is not just feeding but teaching a child to eat with joy, confidence, and safety ‚ù§Ô∏è.

articles.title: Introducing Allergens During Baby's Weaning
articles.teaser: Why timely and well-monitored allergen exposure lowers the risk of food allergies later in life.

cover.caption: Parent offering an allergenic food safely during baby-led weaning.

data.text: Food allergies are among the most common concerns in early childhood.
Parents were once advised to delay allergenic foods, but current evidence shows the opposite: offering tiny, controlled portions early on trains the immune system to tolerate new ingredients.
The modern approach
Leading organizations such as WHO, ESPGHAN, and the American Academy of Pediatrics suggest introducing allergenic foods around six months, when the baby is developmentally ready for solids.
‚ÄúGradual exposure in small amounts builds immune tolerance,‚Äù emphasize pediatric allergists. Always choose a moment when your baby is healthy and free from rashes or colds.
Introduce only one new ingredient at a time and do it earlier in the day so you can observe how your baby reacts.
Major food allergens
The European Union recognizes 14 major allergens: gluten, peanuts, tree nuts, celery, mustard, milk, eggs, sesame, fish, crustaceans, mollusks, soy, sulfites, and lupin.
For infants, the most relevant are eggs, fish, milk, wheat, soy, peanuts, celery, assorted nuts, and sesame.
When and how to start
Begin allergen exposure once your baby comfortably handles vegetables, cereals, and meats.
‚Ä¢ Start with micro portions ‚Äî just a crumb or a quarter teaspoon.
‚Ä¢ Increase gradually if no reactions appear and keep a feeding log with dates and amounts.
‚Ä¢ Offer the same allergen again during the week to reinforce tolerance.
Safe allergen introduction checklist
1. Add only one new food at a time so you can pinpoint any reaction.
2. Present the tiniest portion first and serve it during daytime hours.
3. Leave a three-day window before trying a different new food.
4. If the food is well tolerated, repeat it one to two times per week to maintain tolerance.
Possible allergy signs
Watch for redness around the mouth, hives, swelling of the lips or eyelids, coughing, sneezing, breathing difficulties, vomiting, diarrhea, or sudden irritability.
Seek urgent medical attention if you notice trouble breathing, facial swelling, or any signs of anaphylaxis.
If your child already reacted
Do not reintroduce the allergen without guidance from your pediatrician or an allergist. They can advise on supervised challenges and the right timing.
Many children outgrow specific allergies, but it must happen gradually and under expert supervision.
Key takeaway
Allergens are not the enemy when introduced mindfully. Consistent, monitored exposure encourages healthy eating habits and reduces the likelihood of future allergies.
